title: Trustworthy Alignment of Retrieval-Augmented Large Language Models via Reinforcement Learning
abstract: Trustworthiness is an essential prerequisite for the real-world application of large language models. In this paper, we focus on the trustworthiness of language models with respect to retrieval augmentation. Despite being supported with external evidence, retrieval-augmented generation still suffers from hallucinations, one primary cause of which is the conflict between contextual and parametric knowledge. We deem that retrievalaugmented language models have the inherent capabilities of supplying response according to both contextual and parametric knowledge. Inspired by aligning language models with human preference, we take the first step towards aligning retrievalaugmented language models to a status where it responds relying merely on the external evidence and disregards the interference of parametric knowledge. Specifically, we propose a reinforcement learning based algorithm TRUSTWORTHY-ALIGNMENT, theoretically and experimentally demonstrating large language models' capability of reaching a trustworthy status without explicit supervision on how to respond. Our work highlights the potential of large language models on exploring its intrinsic abilities by its own and expands the application scenarios of alignment from fulfilling human preference to creating trustworthy agents. Our code is available at  https://github.com/zmzhang2000/  trustworthy-alignment .

sections.title: Abstract
sections.text: Trustworthiness is an essential prerequisite for the real-world application of large language models. sections.title: 1 Introduction
sections.text: Recent advancement in Large Language Models (LLMs) has significantly boosted the application of Artificial Intelligence (AI) systems across a wide range of fields, such as dialogue assistants (OpenAI, 2023) and autonomous agents (Wang et al., 2023). Researchers contend that one of the most powerful LLMs, _i.e.,_ GPT-4, could reasonably be viewed as a spark of Artificial General Intelligence (AGI) considering its capabilities in language, vision, mathematics, coding, _etc_(Bubeck et al., 2023). Despite these remarkable capabilities, the lack of trustworthiness is still a challenging obstacle to the application of LLMs. As probabilistic models, LLMs occasionally generate output which is plausible but deviating from source input (Adlakha et al., 2023) or factual knowledge (Min et al., 2023; Muhlgay et al., 2023; Li et al., 2023). This phenomenon is referred to as _hallucination_(Maynez et al., 2020; Ji et al., 2023), which poses tangible risks to real-world application scenarios with low tolerance of error such as medical diagnosis (Nori et al., 2023) and legal consultation (Cui et al., 2023; Nguyen, 2023). A common and straightforward approach to mitigate hallucinations in LLMs is to leverage non-parametric knowledge source through _Retrieval-Augmented Generation_(RAG) (Lewis et al., 2020; Shuster et al., 2021). Specifically, RAG retrieves supporting evidence relevant to the source input from an external knowledge base through a retriever, and generates the output conditioning on both the source input and retrieved evidence. The retrieve-and-generate paradigm proves to significantly enhance the factuality and reliability of LLMs (Lewis et al., 2020; Borgeaud et al., 2021; Lazaridou et al., 2022). However, incorporating retrieval into language generation encounters a new problem of _knowledge conflicts_(Longpre et al., 2021) that still impedes the progress towards trustworthy language models. LLMs commonly learn from massive unsupervised data during pre-training and store the learned knowledge in their parameters. Conflict emerges as contextual knowledge in the retrieved evidence contrasting with the inner knowledge stored in LLMs' parameters, which triggers "hallucinations" if an LLM holds a strongbelief in its parametric knowledge and produces response inconsistent with the provided context. This phenomenon is unexpected as the performance of RAG will be restricted by hallucinations if the retrieved evidence is not accurate and helpful enough (Karpukhin et al., 2020; Shi et al., 2023; Ren et al., 2023; Mallen et al., 2023). We focus our research on the retrieval-augmented generation setting where an LLM is deemed trustworthy if it answers questions based on contextual rather than parametric knowledge. A wealth of studies (Longpre et al., 2021; Chen et al., 2022; Neeman et al., 2023; Zhou et al., 2023) has been dedicated to this problem owing to its obstructive impact on trustworthy LLMs. These efforts have discovered LLMs' dilemma between the parameters and retrieved evidence. In other words, LLMs may have capabilities of responding according to both contextual and parametric knowledge, and struggles to determine which to rely on. The inherent capabilities conforms to the foundation of a recently emerged technology in the field of AI: _alignment_(Ji et al., 2023), which aims at encouraging a instruction-following language model (Wei et al., 2022) to behave in line with human intentions and values (Leike et al., 2018) by reinforcement learning from human feedback (RLHF) (Ouyang et al., 2022). It is worth noting that alignment only "unlocks" capabilities LLMs already had, but does not teach new capabilities to the pre-trained and instruction-tuned models (Lowe and Leike, 2022). Inspired by the success of aligning LLMs with human intentions and values, we take the first step towards aligning retrieval-augmented LLM to a trustworthy status where it supplies responses in accordance with merely the retrieved evidence and ignores the parametric knowledge. We hypothesize that LLMs have tendencies of generating response in line with both contextual and parametric knowledge. Based on this, we address the problem of knowledge conflicts by aligning retrieval-augmented LLMs to trustworthy status via reinforcement learning (**Trustworthy-Alignment**). In particular, we elaborate our work by answering the following research questions: * _Does the hypothesis hold that retrieval-augmented LLMs have inherent capabilities of responding according to both contextual and parametric knowledge?_ (Section 2) * _How can we design an algorithm that enhances the trustworthiness of retrieval-augmented LLMs by aligning them to a trustworthy status via reinforcement learning?_ (Section 3) * _How does the proposed algorithm perform and what are the side effects of aligning retrieval-augmented LLMs to trustworthy status?_ (Section 4) We demonstrate that when _merely providing what to achieve_, retrieval-augmented LLMs are capable of aligning itself to a status where it furnishes responses only relying on the contextual knowledge _without explicit supervision on how to respond_. Our work highlights the potential of LLMs on exploring its intrinsic capabilities by its own and expands the application scenarios of alignment from fulfilling human intention and values to creating trustworthy agents.

sections.title: 2 Preliminary Study
sections.text: In this section, we first provide the background of Trustworthy-Alignment by formulating the task of retrieval-augmented generation, and discuss the problem of knowledge conflicts. Subsequently, we introduce answer probability, the proxy metric for model tendency analysis. Finally, we present the model tendency under different human-curated prompts, answering the prerequisite question of our work: (\(RQ_{1}\)) _does the hypothesis hold that retrieval-augmented LLMs have inherent capabilities of responding according to both contextual and parametric knowledge?_

sections.title: Retrieval-Augmented Generation
sections.text: A language model is a parametric probabilistic model \(\pi_{\theta}\) conditioned on the input text. This paper focuses on the question answering (QA) task where the input text is a question \(q\). The generation process is then formulated as sampling a response \(y\) from the language model: \[y\sim\pi_{\theta}(y|q)=\prod_{t=0}^{T-1}\pi_{\theta}(y_{t}|q,y_{<t}), \tag{1}\] where both \(x\) and \(y\) are sequences of tokens, \(t\) is the token index, and \(T\) is the token number of the response. Under the retrieval-augmented setting, we have an additional context \(c\) as a supporting evidence for answering the question, which is typically retrieved from a large knowledge base, _e.g._, Wikipedia. Following Brown et al. (2020), we formulate the retrieval-augmented generation task by reformatting the question \(q\) and context \(c\) as a natural language instruction using a prompting function \(f(q,c)\): \[y\sim\pi_{\theta}(y|q,c)=\prod_{t=0}^{T-1}\pi_{\theta}(y_{t}|f(q,c),y_{<t}). \tag{2}\]

sections.title: Knowledge Conflicts
sections.text: Ideally, a retrieval-augmented LLM responds faithfully in line with the knowledge from \(c\). However, the reality falls short of expectations since we have no idea whether the contextual knowledge in \(c\) or the parametric knowledge in \(\theta\) contributes more to LLM's decision. The _knowledge conflict_(Longpre et al., 2021) emerges when contextual knowledge diverges from the parametric knowledge. We simulate knowledge conflicts by constructing counterfactual data following the entity substitution framework in Longpre et al. (2021). Specifically, we have an original triplet \((q,c^{o},y^{o})\), where \(y^{o}\) is the original right answer of question \(q\) and is included in the context \(c^{o}\) so that it can be inferred from \(q\) and \(c^{o}\). For each sample, we detect the corresponding entity of \(y^{o}\) and replace it with a another entity \(y^{s}\) of the same type. Meanwhile, \(c^{o}\) is transformed to a new context \(c^{s}\) by replacing all of the answer entity mentions. We expect the language model to supply a response including the substituted answer \(y^{s}\) given the counterfactual context \(c^{s}\).

sections.title: Tendency Analysis
sections.text: To validate the prerequisite of our work that retrieval-augmented LLMs have tendencies of delivering response according to both the contextual and parametric knowledge, we conduct tendency analysis on multiple prevalent pre-trained LLMs. For a specific question \(q\) and the counterfactual context \(c^{s}\), we construct three candidate responses: the substituted answer \(y^{s}\), the original answer \(y^{o}\) and a none response \(y^{n}\) instantiated as "None of the above". Then we format the question answering problem to a multi-choice task where LLM selects the best response from \(y^{s},y^{o}\) and \(y^{n}\) given \(q\) and \(c^{s}\). We propose _answer probability_ as a proxy for measuring whether the model relies more on contextual or parametric knowledge, computed by \[\pi_{\theta}([\text{OPTION}]|f_{\text{multi-choice}}(q,c^{s},y^{s},y^{o},y^{n} )), \tag{3}\] where [OPTION] is the token of option code, _i.e._, [A], [B] or [C] in out setting. We denote the probabilities of \(y^{s}\), \(y^{o}\) and \(y^{n}\) corresponding to the options as \(p^{s}\), \(p^{\phi}\), \(p^{\theta}\), respectively. We visualize the tendency of three pre-trained LLMs with two types of prompting strategies on the test set of Natural Questions (Fisch et al., 2019) in Figure 1. With both the instruction-based and opinion-based prompts, Llama-2-7b and Llama-2-7b-chat give almost the same probabilities for the substituted and original answer. Vicuna-7b-v1.5 shows maximum sum of the three probabilities, indicating strongest understanding of the multi-choice task. Even so, Vicuna-7b-v1.5 struggles to decisively choose the substituted answer and still has an likelihood around 0.25 to select the original answer. Hence we draw the conclusion that _the hypothesis of LLMs having capabilities of responding according to both the contextual and parametric knowledge holds true_.

sections.title: 3 Trustworthy Alignment
sections.text: The inherent capabilities of responding according to the contextual and parametric knowledge afford the opportunity to control the LLMs' intention in the scenario of knowledge conflict. In this section, we address (\(RQ_{2}\)) by _formulating the LLM as a Markov Decision Process (MDP), introducing_ Trustworthy-Alignment _and providing theoretical analysis for the proposed algorithm_.

sections.title: Llm As An Mdp
sections.text: Typically, an MDP \(\mathcal{M}\triangleq\langle\mathcal{S},\mathcal{A},r,\mathbb{P},\rho_{0},\gamma\rangle\) consists of the state space \(\mathcal{S}\), the action space \(\mathcal{A}\), a reward function \(r\), the transition probability \(\mathbb{P}\), the initial state distribution \(\rho_{0}\) and a discount factor \(\gamma\). The generation process of an LLM is naturally an MDP where each state \(s\in\mathcal{S}\) is the context comprising prompt tokens \(\tilde{a}_{0:m}\) and previously generated tokens \(a_{0:t-1}\). The initial state \(\tilde{s}\) is the sequence of prompt tokens \(\tilde{a}_{0:m}\) sampled from the distribution \(\rho_{0}\).1 Action space \(\mathcal{A}\) is a finite vocabulary \(\mathcal{V}=\{1,\dots,|\mathcal{V}|\}\). Given the current state \(s_{t}=a_{0:t-1}\), the LLM selects an action \(a_{t}\) from \(\mathcal{A}\), identically samples a token from the vocabulary \(\mathcal{V}\) with the distribution \(\pi_{\theta}\) in an auto-regressive manner formulated as \(a_{t}\sim\pi_{\theta}(a_{t}|s_{t})=\pi_{\theta}(a_{t}|a_{0:t-1})\). The transition in LLM is deterministic as the next state \(s_{t+1}\) is definitely transformed into \(a_{0:t}\) after the action \(a_{t}\) is selected. Afterward, a deterministic reward \(r_{t}\) is given by the reward function: \(r_{t}=r(s_{t},a_{t})\). A state is regarded as terminated when a special end-of-text token is selected or the response reaches the max length. We define the state action value function \(Q^{\pi_{\theta}}(s,a)\triangleq\mathbb{E}_{\mathbb{P},\pi_{\theta}}\left[\sum_ {t=0}^{T-1}\gamma^{t}r^{t}|s_{0}=s,a_{0}=a\right]\), which represents the expected return following policy \(\pi_{\theta}\) after taking action \(a\) at the state \(s\). The state value function is defined as \(V^{\pi_{\theta}}=\mathbb{E}_{a\sim\pi_{\theta}}\left[Q^{\pi_{\theta}}(s,a)\right]\), _i.e.,_ the expected Figure 1: Average answer probabilities of the substituted answer \(p^{s}\), original answer \(p^{o}\) and none response \(p^{n}\) for Llama-2-7b, Llama-2-7b-chat (Touvron et al., 2023) and Vicuna-7b-v1.5 (Zheng et al., 2023) with instruction-based and opinion-based prompting strategies. Generating tokens other than option codes is also feasible so that the sum of three probabilities is less than 1. Details of prompts are listed in Appendix E. return following \(\pi_{\theta}\) from state \(s\). The primary objective of optimizing the LLM via reinforcement learning is to maximize the expectation of discounted cumulative reward: \[J(\pi_{\theta})=\mathbb{E}_{\delta\sim\rho_{0}}\mathbb{E}_{a_{0:T-1}\sim\pi_{ \theta}}\left[\sum_{t=0}^{T-1}\gamma^{t}r_{t}\right]. \tag{4}\]

sections.title: Objective Of Trustworthy-Alignment
Theoretical Analysis
sections.text: In this subsection, we theoretically analyze the proposed Trustworthy-Alignment, ensuring the policy's convergence to the trustworthy status. Specifically, we demonstate that the optimal policy for the total reward \(r(s_{t},a_{t})\) is consistent with the optimal policy for the task-specific reward \(r_{t}^{\text{trust}}\), while \(r_{t}^{\text{KL}}\) and \(r_{t}^{\text{col}}\) do not affect the realization of the alignment. Actually, the purpose of designing these regular terms is to accelerate the model's learning procedure in practice (Ng et al., 1999). Formally, we define an original MDP as \(\mathcal{M}\triangleq\langle\mathcal{S},\mathcal{A},r,\mathbb{P},\rho_{0},\gamma\rangle\), where \(\mathcal{S},\mathcal{A},\mathbb{P},\rho_{0},\gamma\) share the same definitions as in Section 3.1. Both \(\mathcal{S}\) and \(\mathcal{A}\) are finite sets, and \(r\) is defined as \(r(s_{t},a_{t},s_{t+1})=r_{t}^{\text{trust}}\).2 A transformed MDP is defined based on the original MDP \(\mathcal{M}\) as \(\mathcal{M}^{\prime}\triangleq\langle\mathcal{S},\mathcal{A},r^{\prime}, \mathbb{P},\rho_{0},\gamma\rangle\), which differs from \(M\) in that the reward function is defined as \(r^{\prime}(s_{t},a_{t},s_{t+1})=r_{t}^{\text{trust}}+r_{t}^{\text{col}}+r_{t}^{ \text{KL}}\). The reward functions of both MDPs are bounded. We will show that the optimal \({\pi^{*}}^{\prime}\) obtained on \(\mathcal{M}^{\prime}\) can be equivalent to the optimal \(\pi^{*}\) obtained on \(\mathcal{M}\). Our analysis approach is similar to the Potential-based Reward Shaping theory (Ng et al., 1999). Firstly, we introduce the definition of the state potential function and provide a lemma. Footnote 2: Note that \(r(s_{t},a_{t},s_{t+1})=r(s_{t},a_{t})\), since \(s_{t+1}\) can be uniquely determined by \(s_{t}\) and \(a_{t}\) in the context of language models. **Definition 3.1**.: For any \(s\in\mathcal{S}\), define its potential function as follows: \[\Psi(s)=g(s)-\alpha_{2}\log P_{\pi_{\theta}}(s)+\alpha_{2}\log P_{\pi^{\text{ SFT}}}(s), \tag{9}\] where \(P_{\pi}(s)=\prod\pi_{\theta}(a_{t}|a_{0:t-1})\) indicates the probability of state \(s\) generated from \(\pi\). It can be known that \(\Psi(s_{t+1})-\Psi(s_{t})=r_{t}^{\prime}-r_{t}=r_{t}^{\text{col}}+r_{t}^{ \text{KL}}\), while the reward function \(r_{t}^{\text{trust}}\) cannot be decomposed into a subtraction of some potential function, as discussed in detail in Appendix A. Using the potential function, we can prove the following lemma about order-preserving properties. **Lemma 3.2**.: _(Order Preserving) There exists a potential function \(\Psi(\cdot)\) such that \(\Psi(s_{t+1})-\Psi(s_{t})=r_{t}^{\prime}-r_{t}\)\(r_{t}\). Given state \(s\in\mathcal{S}\) and policy \(\tilde{\pi}\), for any actions \(a_{1},a_{2}\in\mathcal{A}\), when \(\gamma=1\), if \(Q^{\sharp}_{\mathcal{M}}(s,a_{1})>Q^{\tilde{\pi}}_{\mathcal{M}}(s,a_{2})\), then \(Q^{\tilde{\pi}}_{\mathcal{M}}(s,a_{1})>Q^{\tilde{\pi}}_{\mathcal{M}}(s,a_{2})\). Otherwise, assume \(Q^{\tilde{\pi}}_{\mathcal{M}}\) is continuous function with respect to \(\gamma\), when \(\gamma\) is sufficiently close to \(1\), if \(Q^{\tilde{\pi}}_{\mathcal{M}^{\prime}}(s,a_{1})>Q^{\tilde{\pi}}_{\mathcal{M}^ {\prime}}(s,a_{2})\), then \(Q^{\tilde{\pi}}_{\mathcal{M}}(s,a_{1})>Q^{\tilde{\pi}}_{\mathcal{M}}(s,a_{2})\)._ The proof can be found in Appendix A. This lemma indicates that when \(\gamma\) is large enough, for the same policy, the relative numerical relationship of the Q-function of the transformed MDP \(\mathcal{M}^{\prime}\) is consistent with the original MDP \(\mathcal{M}\). Therefore, we can obtain the following consistency and convergence theorem. **Theorem 3.3**.: _(Consistency and Convergence) Assume \(Q^{\tilde{\pi}}_{\mathcal{M}}\) is a continuous function with respect to \(\gamma\), when \(\gamma\) is sufficiently close to \(1\), the optimal policy obtained in MDP \(\mathcal{M}^{\prime}\) is also the optimal policy in MDP \(\mathcal{M}\). The policy \(\pi^{\prime}\) obtained from the training of the RL algorithm has the following error bounds with the optimal policy, where \(\pi^{*}\) is the optimal policy on \(\mathcal{M}\), \(\epsilon=\left\|\mathcal{T}Q^{\pi^{\prime}}_{\mathcal{M}}-Q^{\pi^{\prime}}_{ \mathcal{M}}\right\|_{\infty}\), \(\mathcal{T}\) is the Bellman Optimal Operator:_ \[\left\|V^{\pi^{\prime}}_{\mathcal{M}}-V^{\pi^{*}}_{\mathcal{M}}\right\|_{ \infty}\leq\frac{2\gamma\epsilon}{1-\gamma}. \tag{10}\] The proof is detailed in Appendix A. According to the theorem, we guarantee that LLMs trained with Trustworthy-Alignment converge to the trustworthy status.

sections.title: 4 Experiments
sections.text: In this section, we conduct experiments and analyze Trustworthy-Alignment to answer (\(RQ_{3}\)) _how does the proposed algorithm perform and what are the side effects of aligning retrieval-augmented LLMs to trustworthy status._ We first detail the datasets, metrics and compared baselines. Then we analyze the performance, generalization capability, alignment tax and human evaluation of Trustworthy-Alignment. Finally, we investigate the impact of individual components of Trustworthy-Alignment by carrying out ablation studies on annealing exploration, scaling law and critic model.

sections.title: 4.1.1 Datasets
sections.text: Following the setting of prior works (Longpre et al., 2021; Chen et al., 2022), we take the open-domain question answering task as a showcase of knowledge conflicts in the retrieval-augmented language model generation. We train Trustworthy-Alignment on the MRQA Workshop Shared Task's version3(Fisch et al., 2019) of **Natural Questions**(Kwiatkowski et al., 2019). To be specific, we create the counterfactual version of Natural Questions by replacing the answer and all of its mentions in the context with another same type entity from the same dataset, following the substitution framework in Longpre et al. (2021). The original and substituted version of training set is used for training while only substituted version of dev set is used for evaluation. Footnote 3: There is a significant amount of duplicate data in the training set. We deduplicate the dataset for unbiased training. Despite that the substituting framework is straightforward, Xie et al. (2023) argues that evidence synthesized by simply substituting entities in the context is too incoherent to convince LLMs. And thus they construct a more coherent and convincing dataset **ConflictQA** on top of an entity-centric QA dataset **PopQA**(Mallen et al., 2023) and a multi-step reasoning dataset **StrategyQA**(Geva et al., 2021) by prompting LLMs to directly generate supporting evidence that contradicts the parametric memory. We evaluate the generalization capability of Trustworthy-Alignment by testing the performance of LLMs trained on Natural Questions on ConflictQA generated from GPT-4. Besides, to evaluate the alignment tax, we test performance change of the aligned model on **Open LLM Leaderboard4** tasks, including grade-school science AI2 Reasoning Challenge(Clark et al., 2018), commonsense inference **HelsWag**(Zellers et al., 2019), multitask language understanding **MMLU**(Hendrycks et al., 2021), truthful generation **TruthfulQA**(Lin et al., 2022), commonsense reasoning **Winogrande**(Sakaguchi et al., 2021) and multi-step mathematical reasoning **GSM8k**(Cobbe et al., 2021). Footnote 4: [https://huggingface.co/spaces/HuggingFaceH4/open_llm_leaderboard](https://huggingface.co/spaces/HuggingFaceH4/open_llm_leaderboard)

sections.title: 4.1.2 Metrics
sections.text: We evaluate the response of LLM given the question and substituted evidence. For free-form QA dataset Natural Questions, we report the average _best subspan exact match_ (EM) indicating if the answer entity appears in the response. Samples in ConflictQA is transformed into multiple-choice QA format following Xie et al. (2023) and thus we directly assess the _accuracy_ (Acc) for this dataset. Additionally, we adopt memorization ratio (Longpre et al., 2021)\(M_{R}=\frac{p_{o}}{p_{o}+p_{o}}\) to measure the LLM's capability of forgetting parametric knowledge, where \(p_{o}\) and \(p_{s}\) are the fractions of samples that model predicts the original answer and substituted answer, respectively. Note that \(p_{s}\) is equivalent to average EM and Acc and an LLM is deemed as in trustworthy status if owning a small memorization ratio. Following Longpre et al. (2021), we narrow the evaluation on Natural Questions by only preserving samples that LLM can correctly respond the original answer in a closed-book setting, meaning that the knowledge is originally stored in its parameters. Nevertheless, we do not perform this filter on ConflictQA as multi-choice QA task is profoundly affected by the order of options (Wang et al., 2018; Ko et al., 2020; Wang et al., 2023b; Zheng et al., 2023), which renders the filtering unreliable.

sections.title: 4.1.3 Baselines
sections.text: * **Closed-source Models.** We experiment with two closed-source LLMs, ChatGPT (gpt-3.5-turbo-1106) and GPT-4 (gpt-4-1106-preview)5, to present the state-of-the art performance under the zero-shot setting. Footnote 5: Experiments on the GPT series models are conducted in January, 2024. * **Open-source Models.** We conduct experiments on Llama-2-7b and its fine-tuned version Llama-2-7b-chat that has been optimized for dialogue use cases (Touvron et al., 2023). Besides, we also evaluate Vicuna-7b-v1.5 (Zheng et al., 2023) which is fine-tuned from Llama-2-7b with ChatGPT conversation data. * **Prompt Engineering.** We evaluate the zero-shot performance of these closed-source and open-source LLMs with prompt engineering. An instruction-based and an opinion-based prompting strategy are adopted for all models. All prompts are listed in Appendix E. * **Supervised Fine-tuning.** We perform supervised fine-tuning on open-source LLMs, which directly teaches the LLM how to respond by minimizing the cross entropy between the ground truth answer and output of LLM. Prompt template is fixed to instruction-based form in the supervised fine-tuning and Trustworthy-Alignment.

sections.title: Human Evaluation
sections.text: Despite that we do not intend to align LLMs with human preference via the proposed algorithm, human evaluation is an indispensable evaluation protocol for language generation. Thus, we conduct human evaluations for alignment tax and fluency of Trustworthy-Alignment. Specifically, we randomly select question-context pairs from the test set of Natural Questions, generate responses using pre-trained, supervised-finetuned and trustworthy aligned Llama-2-7b-chat models for each pair. Human evaluators are asked to judge whether the response from supervised-finetuned or trustworthy aligned model is closer to the pre-trained model in terms of language style. Naturally, more similar language style with pre-trained model indicates lower alignment tax. Besides, we ask human evaluators to select their most preferred response out of these three models for measurement of fluency. We collect feedback on 40 question-context pairs from 33 human evaluators, and compute the mean values and standard deviations of win rate for each model. According to the results shown in Figure 3, the responses of Trustworthy-Alignment are significantly more analogous to the pre-trained model and more fluent than SFT model. These results are expected since the RL algorithm in Trustworthy-Alignment reinforces some of the intrinsic outputs of pre-trained LLM, while SFT forces the pre-trained LLM to follow the style of provided demonstration data.

sections.title: Hallucination
sections.text: Hallucination in LLMs is defined as generating content that is nonsensical or contradict to the source input and typically divided into extrinsic and intrinsic hallucinations (Ji et al., 2023). An LLM may present responses that cannot be verified from the source or generated content (Maynez et al., 2020), which is referred to as extrinsic hallucination. Retrieval-Augmented Generation (Lewis et al., 2020) attempts to tackle this type of hallucination by storing knowledge in an extra knowledge base, retrieve and relying on related knowledge during generation. Despite that verifiability is significantly enhanced, the conflict between parametric and contextual knowledge (Longpre et al., 2021) triggers the intrinsic hallucination where LLMs generate outputs inconsistent with retrieved information (Mallen et al., 2023). Longpre et al. (2021) and Neeman et al. (2023) construct counterfactual data and utilize supervised fine-tuning to compel LLMs to focus on the retrieved context. Chen et al. (2022) expand the study of knowledge conflicts to multiple evidence setting and proposes a recalibration method encouraging LLMs to abstain from answering questions in conflict. Prompt engineering is also proved to be effective for improving faithfulness in knowledge conflict situations (Zhou et al., 2023; Si et al., 2023). These dedicated efforts imply inherent capabilities of responding according to parametric and contextual knowledge in LLMs. Based on this, we take the first step towards encouraging LLMs to explore trustworthy status with reinforcement learning where only what to achieve is provided.

sections.title: Alignment
sections.text: Alignment was first introduced to create agents that behave in line with the intention of users (Leike et al., 2018) and boomed in the era of LLMs due to the strong demand for AI assistants harmony with human values (Stiennon et al., 2020; Ouyang et al., 2022). Alignment is achieved by reinforcement learning from human feedback (RLHF) (Christiano et al., 2017) that trains a reward model representing human preference and optimize an instruction-tuned model (Wei et al., 2022) using the reward model. Beyond that, researchers extend the RLHF to reinforcement learning from AI feedback (RLAIF) (Bai et al., 2022) and self-alignment (Sun et al., 2023) that learn with feedback generated from language models to reduce the dependence of human annotations. Moreover, safe RL framework (Garcia and Fernandez, 2015) is integrated into alignment to mitigate the conflict between helpfulness and harmless of LLMs. A grand vision of aligning future superhuman models with weak models (Burns et al., 2023) confirms the long-term value of alignment technology in the development of AGI. Different from existing works that mainly focus on aligning agents with human intention and values, we expand the application scenarios of alignment to creating trustworthy agents.

sections.title: 6 Conclusion
sections.text: In this work, we take the first step towards expanding the application scenarios of alignment technology from fulfilling human intentions to creating trustworthy agents that overcome knowledge conflicts. Specifically, we elaborate our work by verifying the prerequisite hypothesis, design a reinforcement learning algorithm and comprehensively investigate the performance and side effects of the proposed algorithm. We theoretically and experimentally demonstrate LLMs' capability of reaching a trustworthy status without explicit supervision on how to respond. sections.title: Appendix B Annealing Exploration
sections.text: The trade-off between exploration and exploitation is a crucial challenge in RL (Sutton & Barto, 2018) lying also in Trustworthy-Alignment. Exploration is necessary to try out new responses that may hit the correct answer of a given question. Exploitation ensures that the policy select the best option based on currently explored experiences to maximize the long-term benefits. Trustworthy-Alignment trains the LLM in an on-policy manner where experience sampling is conducted using the latest version of its updating parametric policy. The amount of randomness in the response depends on the generation configuration of the current policy, especially the temperature \(\tau\). Large \(\tau\) enhances randomness by spreading the action probability distribution while small \(\tau\) brings more certainty by sticking the most possible action out. Thus, analogous to the decreasing exploration rate in the \(\epsilon\)-greedy policy (Mnih et al., 2015), we propose an _annealing exploration_ strategy where the temperature for experience generation starts from a large value and gradually decreases, to control the trade-off between exploration and exploitation. Specifically, the temperature in training step \(i\) is defined as \[\tau(i)=(1-\frac{i}{N})\tau^{\text{initial}}+\frac{i}{N}\tau^{\text{final}}, \tag{22}\] where \(\tau^{\text{initial}}>\tau^{\text{final}}\), and \(\tau\) anneals linearly from \(\tau^{\text{initial}}\) to \(\tau^{\text{final}}\) over \(N\) total training steps.

sections.title: Alignment To The Parametric Knowledge
sections.text: An assumption for Trustworthy-Alignment is that the retriever is good enough to return contexts containing right answers for given questions. However, this assumption does not always hold true. To provide a potential solution for trade-off between parametric and contextual knowledge, we conduct experiment on probing parametric knowledge of LLMs via Trustworthy-Alignment. Specifically, we modify the reward in Equation (5) to \[r_{t}^{\text{trust}}=\begin{cases}+\alpha_{0}&\text{if }s_{t+1}\text{ ends }\wedge(y^{s}\subseteq s_{t+1}\lor y^{o}\subseteq s_{t+1})\\ -\alpha_{1}&\text{if }s_{t+1}\text{ ends }\wedge y^{s}\nsubseteq t_{t+1}\wedge y^{o} \nsubseteq t_{t+1}\\ 0&\text{otherwise}\end{cases}, \tag{23}\] with which the model is also rewarded when the original answer appears in the response. We conduct experiment with Llama-2-7b-chat and report the proportion of samples whose responses contain the substituted, original and both answers and memorization ration in Table 5. It can be observed that \(p^{o}\), \(p^{both}\) and \(M_{R}\) significantly improves with a simple modification on the reward coefficients, indicating Trustworthy-Alignment's encouraging effect on recalling much more parametric knowledge. We reckon this ability a potential solution for the imperfect retriever and will take a deep dive into this research question in our future work. In addition, it is worth noting that \(p^{s}\) decreases slightly after the modified alignment. We check the exploration process in the training of LLM and find few responses in the collected experiences including both the contextual and parametric answers. A possible explanation is that pre-trained Llama-2-7b-chat is too weak to generate experience that includes both answers and to be reinforced. And thus reaching a response mode produce responses containing both the original and substituted answers is hard for small models.
